2693.text: Kuk Ber is normally played at weddings.

2697.text: At the end of the celebration, when everyone has had plenty of vodka to drink,

2701.text: the bride’s father throws a skin onto the ground,

2703.text: and the person that manages to carry it to the ger of the bride’s parents will receive a prize – a yak.

2709.text: The difficulty is not just fighting against the other guests –

2713.text: often, the bride’s house is so far away that the game can go on for several hours…

2717.text: but a yak is a prize well worth fighting for.

2773.text: The day of the competition dawns clear and sunny.

2783.text: Since the first light of morning,

2786.text: the participants have been taking up their positions at the top of a hill.

2789.text: A certain nervousness can be felt in the air,

2793.text: and not only because it is the first time that so many hunter have come together to test their skill,

2798.text: but also because yesterday, inside the gers,

2801.text: many bets were laid, and some may have yet rather too much.

2813.text: The first part of the competition consists of releasing the eagles,

2817.text: one by one, on the signal of a pennant, towards a fox skin pulled along by a horse.

2833.text: The five birds of prey that take least time to reach the fox skin

2837.text: will go into the final, where this time the target  will be a live fox.

2874.text: Evening is drawing in, and the five finalists are ready for

2877.text: the grand final. Kumarkán, the master hunter, is one of them.

2943.text: The competition has ended, and the participants go to collect their eagles.

2956.text: Kumarkan was not the winner, but he doesn’t mind too much.

2958.text: Next year, he will return with his son Talaikán and his friends,

2964.text: to once again share an art and a tradition which here remains alive,

2968.text: but which unfortunately in his homeland, neighbouring Kazakhstan, died out long ago.

2979.text: With no noisy farewells, and more or less in silence,

2982.text: the hunters slowly leave Jorjok and head out into their world

2985.text: of infinite spaces and vast horizons.

2999.text: In the Gobi desert, in the middle of October,

3001.text: the grass is drying. For the Tansendarya clan,

3006.text: it is time to gather up camp and set off towards less harsh lands in which to spend the winter.

3019.text: The cattle and part of the family left at daybreak,

3021.text: while the rest have remained, loading the camels and organising the caravan.

3033.text: For eight days they will walk, moving northwest to the edge of the desert.

3037.text: Then, at the start of spring, they will travel up into the highlands of the steppe,

3043.text: only to return later to the Gobi.

3046.text: That is what their ancestors did, that is what they do,

3050.text: and that is what their children will do.

3058.text: And that is the story of three ethnic groups that live in a world of constant movement,

3062.text: struggling to preserve their most valuable treasure, their culture,

3068.text: is being wiped out by a society engaged in a headlong rush towards globalisation.
